course.subject: MATH
course.name: Foundation of Mathematics
course.description: This course covers a number of foundational concepts and rigorous reasoning in mathematics which are essential for intermediate- and upper levels mathematics courses especially in the field of pure mathematics. The main purpose of the course is to enhance students’ conceptual and logical understanding of mathematics, and strengthen students’ ability on writing mathematical proofs. Topics include mathematical induction, set notations and logic, complex numbers, inequalities, construction of real numbers, elementary number theory, etc.
course.prerequisites: Level 5 or above in HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M2 OR MATH 1012 OR MATH 1013 OR MATH 1020 OR MATH 1023

集合、量词（∃ and ∀）、证明、数学归纳法
简单。
-集合与映射
集合、并交补、映射、像与原像、单射与满射、逆、等价关系

自然数、整数、有理数、实数、指数、复数

整除、小数、素数、分解因数/因式、最大公约数、同余、整除判别方法。
小学奥数罢了。
-计数
有穷、无穷、势、序、可数性
之前没学过，但是简单。

Basically the contents of Professor Yan's MATH110 20 years ago.

The level of difficulty varies greatly among topics.
For example, 4.1 Quotient and Remainder is quite easy, but 3.6 Real Number is quite hard to understand.

This course is a required course for pure math majors, but according to Professor Fong, Tsz Ho, all the stuff taught in this course can be learnt more in-depth in other required courses, so I am not sure why he still decided to revive this course.

reviews.comment_teaching:
The course instructor is Professor Yan.
The TAs are Kailong Gao and Zhongyi Shi.

There are 2 80 minutes lectures and 1 50 minutes tutorial per week.
Attendence is not taken for both lectures and tutorials.
Professor Yan also opened a WeChat group for us, but I did not join group.
Note that I attended most lectures and all tutorials.

Professor Yan is not too good of a teacher.
His voice is loud and tone is ok.
His English is good but with slight accent.
He writes on the whiteboard with a marker, and font is ok.
He is prepared before the lesson, and gives some extra examples in addition to those in lecture notes.
His teaching speed is ok.
However, even though he tried to explain stuff clearly, he failed to do so. He often overcomplicate stuff, and I had a hard time understanding the contents. It is better to learn by yourself or wait for the TA to explain it again in the tutorials.
Also note that he spend most of the lecture time after the mid term on 3.6 Real Number, but decided to not examine the topic as he think it was too difficult.
He often make mistakes and have a lot of typos in his lecture notes (even the final exam answers are wrong!).
Also, he always receive phone calls (about 2 or 3 per lecture) and pauses the lecture to pick up the phone.
The good thing about Professor Yan is that he gives us short thinking breaks regularly, so that I actually have time to understand what he is talking about.
Bonus: Professor Yan invited us to hike after the mid term.

My TA was Kailong Gao, so i cannot comment about Zhongyi Shi.

Kailong Gao is a below mean TA.
His voice is loud but tone is lazy.
His English is meh and accent is quite heavy but still audible.
He writes on the whiteboard with a marker, and font is ok.
He explains much more clearly than Professor Yan, but unfortunately, I don't think he prepares before tutorials, as his tutorials are basically same as the lectures, and he need to look at the lecture notes before starting every new sentence. He is also quite unorganized, as he taught chapter 4 and 5 in just one tutorial at an extreme pace.
His teaching speed is mostly good though.
I also thinks that he does not communicate with Professor Yan, as Professor Yan announced that 3.7 Exponential is skipped, but Kailong Gao teaches it anyways.
He did welcome questions after tutorials and was quite helpful i terms of answering questions.

In my opinion, treat the lectures as a preview, and treat the tutorials as the real lectures. Also, please learn by yourself.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is kind of bad.

Grading scheme:
Homework 20%
Mid term 30%
Final 50%.

For this year, I guess the mid term was of normal difficulty, but the final was a bit too easy (comparing to MATH110 or MATH2721 finals in the past), and the cut-offs are very very high. If you mess up any of them, your grade is doomed.

Not recommended to take this course unless it is a major requirement, as it allows people who suck at proving (eg. me) to get good grade, while future IRE Math majors get B due to careless mistakes.

Grade book attached below.
reviews.comment_workload:
Average workload for a 3-credit course, but this is a 2-credit course.

Homework is given out about weekly after the add-drop period has ended, and deadline is set at about 1 week after release.
In total, there are 9 homework.
Homework only consists of exercise selected from Professor Yan's lecture notes.
Homework length varies from homework to homework, some can be lengthy while some are quite short. The same goes for homework difficulty.
In general, each homework takes about 2 to 8 hours.

As explanation by Professor Yan or TA are both not too clear, and some content is actually quite challenging, quite some time is needed to understand the concepts. It took me 1 or 2 days to study for the mid term and 2 to 3 days to study for the final.

Both the mid term and final are open-book (technically open internet too as Professor Yan allowed us to use laptops and tablets, but did not check if we are using the Internet), and the difficulty of the final is lower than expected, so you could say that you "do not need to study".

reviews.author: aXRei
reviews.title: Content essential for maths major, but delivered in a poor way
reviews.comment_content:
Once upon a time there were MATH110 and then MATH2721, but they went dead for a long time. FF (Prof. Fong, UG coordinator) said in his blog that he brought back this course (with a new course code) to prepare students for studying maths in the future.

Comment from others: very similar to COMP2711

TLDR:
Introduction to different aspects of pure mathematics
Tests only include easy parts of the lecture content, also questions are ambiguous that Yan Min had to explain them several times.

Giving 3 hours to finish 5 straight-forward problems (which should only take around 1 hour) open-book cannot well distinguish students' ability.
  
The course consists of 5 chapters.

~Before Mid-term~

1. Logic

Statement: sadly the truth table is not introduced (indeed very useful), just be careful with logic (e.g. not (A and B) = not A or not B)

Implication: if A then B, A => B etc. Note that this does not imply B => A. Note that this do not imply causality between A and B (despite the arrow)

Quantifier: For all, There exists. Note that they cannot be interchanged (for all a there exists b is different to there exists b for all a)

Proof: Proof by contradiction, basic proof such as sqrt(2) is irrational

Induction: strong (assume true for all n' < n), weak (assume true for n-1), double (two variables). Note you always need to prove the base case (usually n = 1).

No offence but if you start getting lost in this part you should drop this course and think again whether you are capable of studying maths. I don't mean that this chapter is trivial, but it is the easiest among mathematics

2. Set and Map

Set: Definition, Operations (union, intersection, complement, disjoint union, cartesian product) Note the operations are consistent with logics

Map: Properties of Map, Domain, Range, Image, Pre-image. Note that you can map a set to another, instead of just element to element; Surjectivity, Injectivity, Bijectivity, (Left / Right) Inverse. Note how to use these properties (e.g. prove that f(x) is injective: f(x) = f(y) => x = y). Yan Min's proof on Bijective <=> Invertible is not so accurate, better to read off maths stack exchange

Equivalence Relation: Properties, Equivalence Class, Partition, Quotient Map. TBH this part is quite confusing at first. Note that Equivalence Relation is just generalisation of equality. Two elements are equivalent if they share the same property.

~After Mid-term~

3. Number System

Natural Number: Starting from Peano's Axioms, addition and order can be defined. Their trivial properties are proven from definition and induction

Integers: Defined based on equivalence class of natural numbers.
Rational Numbers: Defined based on equivalence class of integers
Addition and Multiplication for integers and rational numbers are defined. (indeed well-defined i.e. same result with different expression of equivalence class). Later their properties are proven.

Real numbers: Transition from Algebra to Analysis. In this course, real number is constructed from Dedekind cut (infernum of a lower-bounded set of rational numbers). Yan Min said this part is too hard and did not include it in the exam. With real numbers power can be defined (power is not taught)

Complex numbers: we want to know what is sqrt(-1), we did it, at what cost? Well, the numbers can no longer be ordered. Very basic knowledge of complex numbers, such as definition, arithmetic, exponential, conjugate, argument, modulus

You should try to forget basic arithmetic you have been using since primary school. As long as it is not proven, you cannot use it. Luckily for this chapter, there is only 1 problem in final, which is related to solving linear system of equations with complex coefficients. Only DSE M0 knowledge required

5. Counting
Finite counting: Definition of counting, Inclusion-Exclusion Principle
Cardinality: comparing size of infinite sets, Cantor-Schroder-Bernstein Theorem for showing same cardinality (finding injections for both directions)
Countability: Define countability (finite or size of natural numbers), explain why real number is uncountable

The only proof-type question in final is related to counting, but it only uses simple proving by contradiction technique.

4. Number Theory
Quotient and Remainder
Decimal Expansion
Greatest Common Factor
Prime and Factorization
Congruence

Understanding techniques in finding solutions is enough. Euclidean Algorithm is very common in past papers so try to learn how to reconstruct things backward

As this is an introductory course to mathematics, I understand that the content is not in-depth
reviews.comment_teaching:
Yan Min's teaching is controversial, some may think that he teaches well and explains the concepts clearly, but I don't think so.

This is not a bias for a 9am course, but it is quite difficult to follow Yan Min's teaching. Although he usually gives out breaks to give us time to understand what he say, no one understands.
Reading the lecture notes (sadly very confusing and full of typos, quite surprised that the notes had 20 years of history) or even Terrence Tao's Analysis 1 is more efficient.

Also, Yan Min tends to procrastinate and mark our midterms after we finish the final. Nevertheless, he is quite efficient and finishes marking nearly 200 test papers in a few days.

Edit: some of the proofs are confusing to read, ProofWiki and StackExchange will be your good friends.

reviews.comment_workload:
TLDR: average workload

9 Homework sets, all come from lecture notes. Some of the problems are challenging, but most are just playing with definitions for once or twice.

For each homework sets, 3 problems are graded (10 marks each), others are not graded. If you finish them, you get 3 marks per question.

You should refer to math stack exchange to check your answer before submission. Moreover, you can gain insight from the website if you don't know how to finish the problem.

Around 2 hours per week for assignment and revision. Since the tests are open-book, you only need to familiarise with the logic of important proofs

Here are some remarks for two hard chapters. The chapter "Real Number" is about the definition of ℝ and the proofs of its properties, which are extremely complicated, and are based on the topic "Equivalence Relation", which is hard as well. Also, the chapter "Cardinality" is very difficult as you need a lot of experience to properly construct a bijective map between two given sets.

An alternative name to this course is Foundation of Hiking. Out of the blue, prof. Yan Min held a hiking event for students from this course and his MATH 2131 (Honors Linear and Abstract Algebra).
reviews.comment_teaching:
His English accent is easy to follow. He also knows Cantonese and Mandarin, in case you can't explain your questions in English. (Especially helpful for THAT student, if you know what I mean)

He sometimes uses weird notations to explain the content, which can be difficult to follow if you missed his explanations for them. For example, he likes to use 1-1c to represent 1-1 correspondence and a circle to represent the equivalent class of (a,b) with equal a²+b², which can be confusing. Otherwise, he explains every step detailed.

Besides, his teaching is messy. He sometimes suddenly skips from one theorem/topic to another. He also writes messily on the whiteboard, sometimes jumping from one corner of the whiteboard to another.

Lecture notes are updated nearly every week. This can be quite inconvenient for people without iPad or computer. But it's ok for me as I was using an iPad.

There is inconsistent teaching and notation between Yan Min and TA. For example, Yan Min says that the definition of the exponential operator is an optional topic, but TA still teaches it anyways.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 20%
Midterm 30%
Final 50%

There is no exclusion to this course, hence anyone, including year 4 MATH IRE pure math students. Essentially, you are competing with math major seniors.

The mid-term and final exams were approximately 3 hours with 5 questions. However, the time limit was not strict, Yan Min allowed you to continue writing even after 3 hours had passed.

Due to the vagueness of words in his questions (What did it mean by "smallest" equivalent class?), Yan Min explained all of them before the start, but many people still asked for clarifications in the middle of the exams.

Also, you could use your iPad during exams to refer to Yan Min's notes and your own notes. Technically you weren't allowed to use the internet, but no one checked, as Yan Min was the only invigilator. Therefore, someone might be using Math StackExchange secretly. Therefore, there is no guarantee that the exams were fair.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is reasonable. There is one assignment per week with around 10 questions, which roughly takes me 5 hours to finish. Besides, 3 questions will be marked in each homework, and you automatically gain marks for other questions as long as you finished. Finally, you can submit homework late as long as before the release of the solution.

reviews.comment_content:
Description:

This course covers a number of foundational concepts and rigorous reasoning in mathematics which are essential for intermediate- and upper levels mathematics courses especially in the field of pure mathematics. The main purpose of the course is to enhance students’ conceptual and logical understanding of mathematics, and strengthen students’ ability on writing mathematical proofs. Topics include mathematical induction, set notations and logic, complex numbers, inequalities, construction of real numbers, elementary number theory, etc.

Topics:

Logic: statement, quantifier, proof, induction

Set and Map: set, union, intersection, difference, map, image, preimage, onto, one-to-one, inverse, equivalence relation

Number: natural number, integer, rational number, real number, exponential, complex number

Integer and Polynomial: division, decimal expansion, prime, factorisation, greatest common divisor, congruence, divisibility criterion

Counting: finite, infinite, cardinal, ordinal, countability
reviews.comment_teaching: I only attended a few of YM's lessons, and boy were they not worth my time. The thing is not only is it a 9am course (which I hate), the reason you attend his lecture is either to find somewhere else to sit and do your own thing, or listen to him "teaching" us by reciting what the lecture notes say without any new examples etc. I gave up shortly afterwards so I don't know exactly how much the teaching pace have changed.
